items.title: ConnectionError: Socket error during eAPI connection: The read operation timed out
items.body:
Please, note that this BUG s related to: https://github.com/napalm-automation/napalm-ansible/issues/165#issuecomment-582143234

I am using NAPALM to perform config-replace on `Arista DCS-7060SX2-48YC6-R` version ` 4.21.8M-13902577.4218M`.with `pyeapi==0.8.3` The session times out no matter what timeout I configure, either http and https. I can use the library ok for other things like send commands.

I can see the HTTP session up and the configure session created, however no packets are sent/received and configure session remains in `pending`

```
   User              Requests       Bytes in       Bytes out    Last hit
----------------- -------------- -------------- --------------- --------------
   prd2204.svc       456            530905         3856176      12 seconds ago

   User              Requests       Bytes in       Bytes out    Last hit
----------------- -------------- -------------- --------------- ---------------
   prd2204.svc       456            530905         3856176      171 seconds ago
```

```
l1a.r5b1.ams7#show configuration sessions
Maximum number of completed sessions: 1
Maximum number of pending sessions: 5

  Name             State         User                 Terminal
  ------------- ------------- ----------------------- -----------
  napalm_101518    pending        prd2204.svc    command-api
```

```
The read operation timed out
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/federicoolivieri/git/NaC/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 443, in send
    response_content = response.read()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/http/client.py", line 454, in read
    return self._readall_chunked()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/http/client.py", line 561, in _readall_chunked
    chunk_left = self._get_chunk_left()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.7.0/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/python3.7/http/client.py", line 544, in _get_chunk_left
```

items.title: pyeapi should migrate to importlib and eliminate use of the imp module
items.body:
We ran into a threading issue on the napalm library which uses pyeapi for Arista connectivity. The threading issue pertained to imports. I somewhat doubt this was the fundamental issue, but definitely looks like an issue which should be fixed in pyeapi (i.e. imp should be replaced with importlib and current imp implementation in pyeapi is not using locks).

``` 
/home/kbyers/VENV/incendio_test/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyeapi/utils.py:34: DeprecationWarning: the imp module is deprecated in favour of importlib; see the module's documentation for alternative uses
    import imp
```

Also on the `imp` documentation:

```
Source code: Lib/imp.py

Deprecated since version 3.4: The imp package is pending deprecation in favor of importlib.
```

items.title: Update to work with old and new CLI syntax
items.body: https://www.arista.com/en/support/advisories-notices/fieldnotices/7097-field-notice-39

items.title: VRRP module not getting the VRID information from an interface
items.body:
Hello,

I am using the `vrrp.get(<interface>).get(vrid)` method to collect VRRP group information but it seems  it is not retrieving any data. Below I am pasting what I am receiving along with the configuration on the switch:

**Swtich configuration**
```
interface Vlan177
   load-interval 5
   ip address 10.177.0.68/28
   vrrp 70 priority 200
   vrrp 70 ip 10.177.0.70
   vrrp 70 track ETH46 shutdown
   vrrp 71 priority 200
   vrrp 71 ip 10.177.0.71
   vrrp 71 shutdown
   vrrp 72 priority 200
   vrrp 72 ip 10.177.0.72
   vrrp 72 shutdown
```

**Python Example**
```
vrrp = node.api('vrrp')
>>> pprint(vrrp.get('Vlan177').get(71))
{'bfd_ip': '',
 'delay_reload': None,
 'description': '',
 'enable': True,
 'ip_version': None,
 'mac_addr_adv_interval': 30,
 'preempt': True,
 'preempt_delay_min': 0,
 'preempt_delay_reload': 0,
 'primary_ip': None,
 'priority': None,
 'secondary_ip': [],
 'timers_advertise': None,
 'track': []}
>>> pprint(vrrp.get('Vlan177').get(70))
{'bfd_ip': '',
 'delay_reload': None,
 'description': '',
 'enable': True,
 'ip_version': None,
 'mac_addr_adv_interval': 30,
 'preempt': True,
 'preempt_delay_min': 0,
 'preempt_delay_reload': 0,
 'primary_ip': None,
 'priority': None,
 'secondary_ip': [],
 'timers_advertise': None,
 'track': []}
```

You can see from the collected data that the `priority = None`, when the configuration is stated as 200, and even though the `vrrp 71 shutdown` it returns it as `enabled = True`.

Was this working before? should I use another method?

Thanks,

items.title: How to execute ``reload`` (to reboot the device)
items.body:
Hello,

I've been searching in the documentation http://pyeapi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html, and briefly looked through the code, but I couldn't find a way to be able to reboot the switch (necessary after an OS upgrade). Is this something achievable via pyeapi? Thanks!

items.title: Allow user to specify the version of json command output
items.body:
Some commands have multiple output versions.  The first (version 1) is the default unless otherwise specified in the request. Example: `show management cvx`.

Valid values: `r'^\d+|latest$'`

kwargs are passed all the way up to the request method which can override the default (1) to a specified value:
https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/5470f3b16fac830b101db35ca32068e62abb0162/pyeapi/eapilib.py#L299

items.title: API doesn't support authentication other than username/password
items.body: Please provide support for some method other than username/password in a text file to access the API. SSH support exists for SSH keys, maybe allow the same key to be used to generate client x.509 certificates.

items.title: Password leaked in debug mode
items.body:
Hi,

The password is leaked in the logs in debug mode: https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/develop/pyeapi/eapilib.py#L256. This is a security issue. Could you remove it?

Thanks.

items.title: Connection failure due to bad username/password fails to report reason
items.body:
Upon attempting to connect with bad credentials, a ConnectionError is reported with the following information:

`````
pyeapi.eapilib.ConnectionError: unable to connect to eAPI
`````
There could be a few reasons for this, I would imaging, for example, the device not being configured / enabled for eAPI.

But the actual device response_content value in the underlying eapilib.py file, when debugged, provides the root cause:

````
(Pdb) pp(response_content)
'Unable to authenticate user: Bad username/password combination'
````

It would be very helpful if this information (response_content) could be bubbled up as an additional argument value to the ConnectionError.

Thank you!

items.title: Error handling for bad authentication
items.body:
Can error handling be added to support a bad username/password in pyeapi?

The behavior as of right now using 0.8.1 against vEOS lab running 4.18.1F and python 3 is the following:
```Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\pyeapi\eapilib.py", line 402, in send
    decoded = json.loads(response_content)
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\__init__.py", line 354, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\decoder.py", line 339, in decode
    obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\decoder.py", line 357, in raw_decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\pyeapi\eapilib.py", line 402, in send
    decoded = json.loads(response_content)
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\__init__.py", line 354, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\decoder.py", line 339, in decode
    obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
  File "C:\Python\Python36-32\lib\json\decoder.py", line 357, in raw_decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".\eAPI-test.py", line 13, in <module>
    config_show = node.execute(['show interfaces Ethernet1', 'show interfaces Ethernet2'])
  File "C:\pyeapi\eapilib.py", line 495, in execute
    response = self.send(request)
  File "C:\pyeapi\eapilib.py", line 428, in send
    raise ConnectionError(str(self), error_msg)
pyeapi.eapilib.ConnectionError: unable to connect to eAPI
```

In the event of a bad authentication the switch responds with HTTP 401 Unauthorized and string `Unable to authenticate user: Bad username/password combination`. When passed to the JSON Decoder in the eapilib.py it cascades with multiple exceptions since it is not a JSON format.

items.title: RHEL7.4 certificate verify failed
items.body:
Hi there

After upgrading from RHEL 7.3 to 7.4 and pyeapi 0.7.0 to 0.8.1 I can't connect to a switch anymore getting the following error.
```
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/pyeapi/client.py", line 672, in enable
    **kwargs)
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/pyeapi/client.py", line 730, in run_commands
    response = self._connection.execute(commands, encoding, **kwargs)
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 495, in execute
    response = self.send(request)
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 428, in send
    raise ConnectionError(str(self), error_msg)
ConnectionError: Socket error during eAPI connection: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed (_ssl.c:579)
```
Python version is 2.7.5 but there might me some backporting done by RedHat which I think is the issue here because the version number does not actually represent the expected functionality regarding SSL.
If I remove the following two lines it works fine.
https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/release-0.8.1/pyeapi/eapilib.py#L67-L68

And here's my code:
```python
try:
    self.node = pyeapi.connect(host=self.host,
                               port=self.port,
                               username=self.user,
                               password=self.pswd,
                               transport=self.prot,
                               return_node=True)
except AttributeError as e:
    self.exitme('Connection parameter not defined: {err}'
                .format(err=e))
```

How can I disable certificate verification?
Any help would be appreciated, thanks!

Regards

items.title: hard coded /command-api was probably a safe default
items.body:
In #129 the fix was to send `self.transport.path` instead of the hard coded `/command-api`.

This breaks any socket connection, because it by default tries to POST to `/var/run/command-api.sock`

*breakage*
```
[ansible@vEOS-lab-4 ~]$ nc -U /var/run/command-api.sock
POST /var/run/command-api.sock HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost
Accept-Encoding: identity
Content-type: application/json-rpc
Content-length: 136

{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "params": {"format": "text", "cmds": ["enable", "show clock"], "version": 1}, "method": "runCmds", "id": "140611372"}
HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request
Server: nginx
Date: Wed, 05 Jul 2017 17:31:39 GMT
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Length: 26
Connection: keep-alive
Cache-control: no-store
Cache-control: no-cache
Cache-control: must-revalidate
Cache-control: max-age=0
Cache-control: pre-check=0
Cache-control: post-check=0
Pragma: no-cache

Invalid endpoint requested
```

You can see this if you `sudo pip install napalm-eos` on your switch which pulls in latest `pyeapi` I guess!

*strace output from running an ansible `ANSIBLE_KEEP_REMOTE_FILES` script*
```
[pid 13894] connect(4, {sa_family=AF_FILE, sun_path="/var/run/command-api.sock"}, 27) = 0
[pid 13894] gettimeofday({1499275467, 441235}, NULL) = 0
[pid 13894] poll([{fd=4, events=POLLOUT}], 1, 60000) = 1 ([{fd=4, revents=POLLOUT}])
[pid 13894] send(4, "POST /var/run/command-api.sock HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: localhost\r\nAccept-Encoding: identity\r\nContent-type: application/json-rpc\r\nContent-length: 136\r\n\r\n{\"jsonrpc\": \"2.0\", \"params\": {\"format\": \"text\", \"cmds\": [\"enable\", \"show clock\"], \"version\": 1}, \"method\": \"runCmds\", \"id\": \"168078828\"}", 280, 0) = 280
[pid 13894] gettimeofday({1499275467, 441403}, NULL) = 0
```

The regression is proven [here](https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/commit/725684d8f966f387d2357b483d6a38d8ecdcfc95) in the commit prior:

```
[ansible@vEOS-lab-4 ~]$ cd /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/
[ansible@vEOS-lab-4 pyeapi]$ sudo curl -o eapilib.py https://raw.githubusercontent.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/725684d8f966f387d2357b483d6a38d8ecdcfc95/pyeapi/eapilib.py
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100 20299  100 20299    0     0   226k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  227k
```

*and then we run the exact same strace*
```
[pid 14494] send(4, "POST /command-api HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: localhost\r\nAccept-Encoding: identity\r\nContent-type: application/json-rpc\r\nContent-length: 136\r\n\r\n{\"jsonrpc\": \"2.0\", \"params\": {\"format\": \"text\", \"cmds\": [\"enable\", \"show clock\"], \"version\": 1}, \"method\": \"runCmds\", \"id\": \"155930028\"}", 267, 0) = 267
[pid 14494] gettimeofday({1499276651, 251797}, NULL) = 0
[pid 14494] poll([{fd=4, events=POLLIN}], 1, 60000) = 1 ([{fd=4, revents=POLLIN}])
[pid 14494] recv(4, "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nServer: nginx\r\nDate: Wed, 05 Jul 2017 17:44:11 GMT\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\nContent-Length: 143\r\nConnection: keep-alive\r\nCache-control: no-store\r\nCache-control: no-cache\r\nCache-control: must-revalidate\r\nCache-control: max-age=0\r\nCache-control: pre-check=0\r\nCache-control: post-check=0\r\nPragma: no-cache\r\n\r\n{\"jsonrpc\": \"2.0\", \"result\": [{\"output\": \"\"}, {\"output\": \"Wed Jul  5 17:44:11 2017\\nTimezone: UTC\\nClock source: local\\n\"}], \"id\": \"155930028\"}", 8192, 0) = 474
[pid 14494] close(4)                    = 0
[pid 14494] socket(PF_FILE, SOCK_STREAM, 0) = 4
[pid 14494] fcntl64(4, F_GETFL)         = 0x2 (flags O_RDWR)
[pid 14494] fcntl64(4, F_SETFL, O_RDWR|O_NONBLOCK) = 0
[pid 14494] connect(4, {sa_family=AF_FILE, sun_path="/var/run/command-api.sock"}, 27) = 0
[pid 14494] gettimeofday({1499276651, 258016}, NULL) = 0
[pid 14494] poll([{fd=4, events=POLLOUT}], 1, 60000) = 1 ([{fd=4, revents=POLLOUT}])
[pid 14494] send(4, "POST /command-api HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: localhost\r\nAccept-Encoding: identity\r\nContent-type: application/json-rpc\r\nContent-length: 174\r\n\r\n{\"jsonrpc\": \"2.0\", \"params\": {\"format\": \"json\", \"cmds\": [\"enable\", \"show version\", \"show hostname\", \"show interfaces\"], \"version\": 1}, \"method\": \"runCmds\", \"id\": \"155930028\"}", 305, 0) = 305
[pid 14494] gettimeofday({1499276651, 258188}, NULL) = 0
```

\o/ we get output!

items.title: Execute does not work well with long running commands
items.body:
When executing a long-running task, a ConnectionError is intermittently raised. From the python console:

```python
eapi = pyeapi.connect(transport='http', host='172.20.1.6', username='user', password='pass')
cmds = ['enable', 'routing-context vrf management', 'copy http://172.20.1.4:8080/images/eos/EOS-4.18.1F.swi flash:']

eapi.execute(commands=cmds, encoding='json')
{u'jsonrpc': u'2.0', u'result': [{}, {}, {u'messages': [u'Copy completed successfully.']}], u'id': u'4542156176'}

eapi.execute(commands=cmds, encoding='json')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/bwatson/Projects/aeon-ztps/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 490, in execute
    response = self.send(request)
  File "/Users/bwatson/Projects/aeon-ztps/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 423, in send
    raise ConnectionError(str(self), 'unable to connect to eAPI')
ConnectionError: unable to connect to eAPI
```

The first copy completed without issue. The second raised a connection error.

items.title: eAPI does not handle commands sent as unicode strings
items.body:
commands passed as unicode should be converted to ascii before being sent to eAPI.  
make_iterable may be a good place.  https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/8c396840de9cdfbf4ee83a78e15ef588b3017448/pyeapi/utils.py#L166

Similar code from elsewhere:
```
            for idx, command in enumerate(commands):
                if isinstance(command, unicode):
                   unicode commands[idx] = str(command)
```

items.title: API path is hardcoded in EapiConnection.send()
items.body: Not sure if this is intended, but no matter what path is specified if calling HttpsEapiConnection directly, send() has /command-api hardcoded, instead of using self.transport.path

items.title: Question: 'timeout' option when running bash commands via the API
items.body:
Hello,

I have just a quick question regarding the execution of bash commands through the API:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "napalm_eos/eos.py", line 1219, in traceroute
    [command], encoding='text')[0].get('output')
  File "/home/mircea/napalm/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/client.py", line 672, in run_commands
    response = self._connection.execute(commands, encoding)
  File "/home/mircea/napalm/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 475, in execute
    response = self.send(request)
  File "/home/mircea/napalm/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 396, in send
    raise CommandError(code, msg, command_error=err, output=out)
pyeapi.eapilib.CommandError: Error [1004]: CLI command 2 of 2 'bash traceroute 8.8.8.8  -m 255 -w 2' failed: incompatible command [Command not permitted via API access. To run a bash command over the Command API,  use the 'timeout  <seconds>' option.]
```

I am not sure how to send the `timeout` option?

Thank you,
Mircea

items.title: 'expandAlias' arg for 'run_commands'
items.body:
Hello,

It looks like the Command API provides support to expand aliases:

![expandalias](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16694679/22107375/4ecc7766-de45-11e6-94d8-3bd69844068b.png)

However, this feature does not seem to be supported by the existing `run_commands` method: https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/master/pyeapi/client.py#L633

Is there any other possibility to run aliases through eAPI?

Thanks,
Mircea

items.title: Cannot run 'no ip virtual-router mac-address' in eos 4.17.x
items.body:
When running `make systests` the VARP-related tests will fail.  The command mentioned in the title is no longer allowed in 4.17.x, as you now have to specify which mac address to remove.

- [ ] Update Varp API
- [ ] Update Unit tests
- [ ] Update System tests

items.title: Non-standard HTTP/s port would cause connection to fail
items.body:
When using an eapi.conf, and setting the port to a non-standard value, eg:

```
[connection:vagrantbox]
host: localhost
username: admin
password: admin
transport: https
port: 8443
```

The connection would fail with:
```
>>> node3.enable('show version')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/phil/eos-plus/pyeapi/pyeapi/client.py", line 619, in enable
    resp = self.run_commands(command, encoding, send_enable)
  File "/Users/phil/eos-plus/pyeapi/pyeapi/client.py", line 672, in run_commands
    response = self._connection.execute(commands, encoding)
  File "/Users/phil/eos-plus/pyeapi/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 475, in execute
    response = self.send(request)
  File "/Users/phil/eos-plus/pyeapi/pyeapi/eapilib.py", line 405, in send
    raise ConnectionError(str(self), 'unable to connect to eAPI')
pyeapi.eapilib.ConnectionError: unable to connect to eAPI
```
when using `connect_to`.

items.title: Add support for EAPI autoComplete feature
items.body: In newer versions of EOS (starting 4.17.1.1 as far as I know) and some specific older versions, EAPI has a hidden feature to allow users to send shortened unambiguous commands as long as the parameter autoComplete=True in the request. This issue is to add support for this feature into pyeapi.

items.title: Add support for VRF Configuration
items.body: Add an API to create VRFs as well as revisit our existing APIs to see where we can effectively add support for VRFs.

items.title: Add more node attributes
items.body: Right now we have basic things like: node.running/startup_config, but it would be nice to automatically create some additional attributes, similar to those found in 'show version'.

items.title: Extended ACLs missing
items.body: Extended ACLs are not supported. Will they ever be?

items.title: test_api_interfaces.TestApiVxlanInterface fails on DUTs running 4.15 and higher
items.body:
If you run the suite of system tests on a DUT running EOS version 4.15.0 or higher the test_get in the TestApiVxlanInterface class fails:

```
FAIL: test_get (test_api_interfaces.TestApiVxlanInterface)
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/Users/dt/eosplus/pyeapi/test/system/test_api_interfaces.py", line 343, in test_get
self.assertEqual(result['multicast_group'], '')
AssertionError: 'decap' != ''
```

This is due to a new EOS command with the following syntax:
`[no] vxlan multicast-group decap`

Therefore the current regex in `_parse_multicast_group` will match on decap when it tries to parse through show running-config all interface vxlan.  The resolution to this issue will be to update the regex in `_parse_multicast_group` to match on a correctly formatted IPv4 multicast group.

items.title: Avoid sending 'enable' for Node.run_commands() method
items.body:
Since we offer Node.enable() to send an array of commands to the node in enable mode, it may be a bit more logical to move the enablement to the same.

Though it is preferred to use config() or enable(), we still allow the usage of run_commands() and enable() actually calls it, so it seems there is a separation that would make sense.

The reasoning here is that if you use command authorization, and you are already a privileged user, we will needlessly send 'enable' with every command.  This adds latency and logs to the command authorization server get spammed.  

If a user tries to invoke run_commands() for a command that is not authorized, it should probably respond with an exception or I suppose the CAPI error text, and then they can decide to use the enable() method instead.

items.title: Review OSPF API
items.body:
- [x] Validate OSPF API
- [x] Increase code coverage (shoot for 100%)
- [x] Validate system tests
- [x] Check doc strings formatted properly
- [ ] Build Readthedocs with OSPF API

items.title: Pyeapi support for windows
items.body:
Customer having trouble in installing pyeapi on windows. The issue is that Python cannot find the syslog module which is a dependency of pyeapi as there does not appear to be one available for Windows.     To make this fully work on Windows, we would need to refactor the code to use the logging module instead of syslog.

Temp solution: We could try the solution at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25537419/python-import-syslog-on-windows which simply creates stubs for the syslog calls to satisfy the parser but does nothing with any data sent to it.

items.title: Update Dev install instructions
items.body: Add pip install -r dev-reqs

items.title: ACL add_entry() should accept an optional seqno
items.body: Currently, add_entry() does not accept a seqno, meaning it only appends entries.  The seqno should be possible to specify for any entry so users can define the numbering scheme and insert statements in any order.

items.title: Update vrrp.py method get_tracks for validation of keys
Update modules to take disable=(True/False) instead of overloading value
items.body:
Instead of setting value=None to negate, use a disable keyword argument.
This may involve updating ansible-eos modules as well.

items.body:
I'm using the latest ansible module for portchannel and getting the following error:

```
failed: [spine2] => {"failed": true}
msg: set_members() got an unexpected keyword argument 'mode'
failed: [spine1] => {"failed": true}
msg: set_members() got an unexpected keyword argument 'mode'

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting
```

It looks like `pyeapi` has been updated to support this in the `interfaces` api with the `mode` arg in the `set_members` method, but it's not installing the latest from pip.

That said, I'm also getting an error installing from source.

Thanks,
Jason

items.title: [API BGP] _parse_shutdown can't accurately determine shutdown state
items.body: The parse was using a simple check for 'no neighbor NAME shutdown'.  This isn't satisfactory.  The neighbor can be active, or idle and the configuration omits 'no neighbor NAME shutdown'  This was causing pyeapi to report the neighbor was shutdown when it really isn't.  Some more research needs to be done here since there's also a shutdown state for the peer_group (if you add the neighbor to it).

items.title: Make eapi.conf file format consistent with rbeapi
Describe the [DEFAULT] feature in the docs
items.body:
Eg

```
[connection:bob]
host: bob.example.com

[DEFAULT]
transport: http
username: admin
password: admin
```

items.title: Add lacp_mode keyword argument to Port-Channel set_members method
items.body:
Right now the set_members method only takes a list of members.  Inside the method it tries to look at existing members to determine the lacp_mode.  This doesn't work when adding the first members to the channel-group.  This enhancement would add a keyword arg that would supercede the lacp_mode present on other members (if found).

Related to https://github.com/arista-eosplus/ansible-eos/issues/36

items.title: Specify timeout
items.body:
Hello,
I sent you the PR #41. I want to be able to specify the timeout value for my connection.

Thanks!
David

items.title: failure when eapi.conf is not formatted correctly
items.body:
pyeapi should not crash when an eapi.conf file is not properly formatted.   Perhaps we could wrap SafeConfigParser in a try/except block and just throw a warning that the file did not parse.

Background, in some cases, where the application does not make use of the eapi.conf, but uses the connect() method, instead, the existence of a file named eapi.conf could cause the application to fail.

items.title: Simplifying connect() function when not using .eapi.conf
items.body:
I am using pyeapi in a context where I want arguments like username/password to come from the Ansible inventory (potentially from Ansible's vault) and not from .eapi.conf.

I look into the code a bit and was messaging with Ryan Madsen of Arista. connect_to function looks to be hard-coded to use the arguments from the .eapi.conf file. I then tried to just use the connect() method.

eapi_conn = pyeapi.connect(transport='https', host='1.1.1.1', username='admin', password='passw', port=8443)

After I did this, I would get the following message when I tried to execute my Ansible playbook. 

AttributeError: 'HttpsEapiConnection' object has no attribute 'enable'

In other words, I expected that I would have the same methods available to me as I had with the connect_to() call. I looked at what you did with connect_to() call and I could see that you were creating a Node() instance.

Ryan then pointed out I could do the following:

> cnxn = pyeapi.client.connect(transport="https", host="lf240", username="admin", password="foo")
> node = pyeapi.client.Node(cnxn)

I think it would be better if you did one of the following:
1. Have the connect() method return a Node object. I don't know if there are uses of connect() without creating a Node object (i.e. whether doing this breaks backwards compatibility). If backwards compatibility is an issue, then you could add a function parameter like 'return_node=False' and have it default to False so that the behavior only changes if someone calls it with the new argument).
2. Update the package **init**.py file and **all** list to add the Node class. This would make it clearer that you potentially intended users to directly use this class (and then add a message to the docstring for the connect() function on how connect can be used with the Node class).

items.title: client.py 'def enable' returned dictionary key inconsistency
items.body:
in client.py 'def enable', line 588, the returned key is "response" if the encoding is enforced (strict=True).

in line 595, the returned key is "result" if the encoding is not enforced.

Wouldn't this create difficulties when writing code to parse the output, that the user needs to worry about when to look for "response" and when to look for "result"?

items.title: [API Users] Can't run set_role with no value
items.body:
You can't run the CLI command: 'username test no role', which is what is used when you 
invoke: node.api('users').set_role('test')

As an aside, this missed testing because the function names weren't prefixed with test_ so python's unittest never ran them.

The faulty code is:

```
        cmd = 'username %s' % name
        if value is not None:
            cmd += ' role %s' % value
        else:
            cmd += ' no role'
        return self.configure(cmd)
```

This works:

```
        cmd = 'username %s' % name
        if value is not None:
            cmd += ' role %s' % value
        else:
            cmd = 'default username %s role' % name
        return self.configure(cmd)
```

items.title: [API Users] Can't run set_privilege with no value
[API: users.py] Add support for sshkey entries
items.body: When an sshkey is provided for an existing user it is presented on the following line in the running config. Example: ``` username phil privilege 1 secret 5 $1$wFlW...dbeRG0 username phil sshkey ssh-rsa AAAAB3...GZv ``` Therefore, we need a regex with a backreference to store the first line's username group and then search for it on the following like. Some initial testing done here: pythex sample

items.title: Enhancement - Allow creation of Ethernet Sub-Interfaces
items.body:
These are slightly different from regular Ethernet interfaces in that they are logical and can be added/removed.

failed: [do324] => (item={'enable': True, 'name': 'Ethernet50/1.100'}) => {"failed": true, "item": {"enable": true, "name": "Ethernet50/1.100"}}
msg: creating Ethernet interfaces is not supported

From interfaces.py:

def create(self, name):
        """Creating Ethernet interfaces is currently not supported
        Args:
            name (string): The interface name
        Raises:
            NotImplementedError: creating Ethernet interfaces is not supported
        """
        raise NotImplementedError('creating Ethernet interfaces is '
                                  'not supported')

items.title: [ API interfaces ] get_members regex wrongly includes PeerEthernet when lag is up
items.body:
get_members will return duplicates of the member interface due to the liberal regex and this output:

```
switch>show port-channel 3 Port Channel Port-Channel3:
  Active Ports:
      Port                  Time became active       Protocol    Mode
      ----------------------------------------------------------------------- 
      Ethernet3          15:33:41                         LACP       Active
      PeerEthernet3  15:33:41                         LACP       Active
```

Note that get_members uses show port-channel N all-ports to get the current members.  Therefore we need to change the regular expression to omit anything with Peer*.

https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/develop/test/unit/test_client.py#L256

```
    def test_connect_to_with_config(self):
        transport = Mock()
        with patch.dict(pyeapi.client.TRANSPORTS, {'https': transport}):
            conf = get_fixture('eapi.conf')
```

items.title: [API MLAG] _parse_peer_link doesn't return full Port-ChannelN
items.body:
Using the interpreter to get the current mlag config:

```
>>> import pyeapi
>>> 
>>> node = pyeapi.connect_to('veos_test_03')
>>> mlag = node.api('mlag').get()
>>> 
>>> 
>>> print mlag
{'interfaces': {}, 'config': {'shutdown': False, 'peer_address': '10.0.0.2', 'local_interface': 'Vlan1024', 'domain_id': 'mlag1', 'peer_link': 'Port'}}
```

Note `peer_link` is just Port.

To fix this change the regex on line 161 https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/develop/pyeapi/api/mlag.py#L161 to

```
peer-link (\S+)
```

items.title: [API] users - can't create password with non-alpha/int characters
items.body:
According to the EOS configuration guide

"
Valid usernames begin with A-Z, a-z, or 0-9 and may also contain any of these characters:
@#$%^&*()-_= +{}[];<>,.~|
"

But when you try to do that in pyeapi:

```
>>> node = pyeapi.connect_to('veos_test_01')
>>> users = node.api('users')
>>> users.getall()
{'admin': {'privilege': '1', 'nopassword': False, 'secret': '$1$g2dMhkqJ$WjdvCWpil3tXDWHXu.nmD1', 'role': 'network-admin', 'format': '5'}}
>>> 
>>> users.create_with_nopassword('a@#$%^&*()-_=+{}[];<>,.~|')
False
```

items.title: Users with sha512 passwords don't get processed correctly using api('users').getall()
items.body:
Given the cli user:

```
username test secret sha512 $6$somesalt$rkDq7Az4Efjo.0vtRe7E/8UXZNB6.88eMNIaqLdpmULIFkw3gDNPFnjAX4Y9fiGFzVlOyaDr1X.YYUsczCeMH.
```

If you run api('users').getall()

```
'test': {'privilege': '1', 'nopassword': False, 'secret': '', 'role': '', 'format': ''}
```

After digging around, if I change the regex from:

```
    users_re = re.compile(r'username ([^\s]+) privilege (\d+)'
                          r'(?: role ([^\s]+))?'
                          r'(?: (nopassword))?'
                          r'(?: secret ([0,5,7]) (.+))?', re.M)
```

to

```
    users_re = re.compile(r'username ([^\s]+) privilege (\d+)'
                          r'(?: role ([^\s]+))?'
                          r'(?: (nopassword))?'
                          r'(?: secret (0|5|7|sha512) (.+))?', re.M)
```

It then works and returns:

```
'test': {'privilege': '1', 'nopassword': False, 'secret': '$6$somesalt$rkDq7Az4Efjo.0vtRe7E/8UXZNB6.88eMNIaqLdpmULIFkw3gDNPFnjAX4Y9fiGFzVlOyaDr1X.YYUsczCeMH.', 'role': '', 'format': 'sha512'}
```

items.title: Broaden the regex matching for portchannel member interfaces
items.body: Line 590, need to fix regex just like we did for rbeapi. Make sure it does not catch PeerEthernetX and make sure it catches Ethernet1 and Ethernet52/1/1

items.title: users.py encryption/format object uniformity
items.body:
Ref: https://github.com/arista-eosplus/pyeapi/blob/develop/pyeapi/api/users.py#L134

There's a lack of uniformity in the module concerning format and encryption (as I can tell).

When you run .get(name) you get an object like:

```
>>> users.get('gertie')
{'privilege': '8', 'nopassword': False, 'secret': '$1$MQZr6HMw$JxamK.dYxewxYdawMgoZU/', 'role': 'network-admin', 'format': '5'}
```

Where format is the cli-ish value of the secret. The difference is in the create\* methods.  They use a param named encryption that abstracts the cli keys to cleartext, md5, sha5.  Wouldn't it be nice to change the output of get() to return a format key in the style of encryption?

items.title: Don't allow deletion of 'admin' user
items.body: Within users.py, raise error if trying to delete the default admin user

items.title: Performance improvement for sending requests
items.body:
The Capi team discovered a 40 ms delay that happens on subsequent requests to a keepalive connection between when the client sends its headers and when it sends the rest of the data (this is due to an interaction of a deferred ACK on the server side and nagle's algorithm on the client side). This can be addressed by sending the data in the endheaders request.

It would also be nice to have a benchmark of the pyeapi library so that we can see the performance improvement of this change.

items.title: Default to using unix socket (if running locally) in order to simplify configuration
connection:localhost not present if not eapi.conf file is found
items.body:
If the client instance is unable to find a valid eapi.conf file to load, the config is empty.  It should always have a default connection profile for localhost using sockets.  

A temporary workaround for this issue is to create an empty eapi.conf file


items.title: Default section in eapi.conf doesn't work in version published on pypi
items.body: Need to investigate whether this is expected or not.

items.title: Minor issues in README.md
items.body:
Line 40-41: 'Each node section must be prefaced by **connection:<name>** where
<name> is the name of the connection.'
   The '<name>' is not displaying on the github webpage that displays the README.md file.

The default values for username, password, enablepwd are not specified.

Line 97 - '## Configuring [connection:localhost]' section
Might be useful to document the minimum EOS release where the socket transport is supported.

Line 209: ^contributes^contributions

items.title: change the message returned from command error
items.body:
Sounds great! Perhaps even go one step further and include node.connection.error.command_error in the stringification of CommandError? I think most users won't remember to look at this field, and it usually holds the interesting data. Perhaps we don't want to include it in the stringification of certain error message, but if error.code == 1000 (general error), then it is definitely more useful to get the actual message.

continuation of issue #4

items.title: Expose specific error messages in eapilib.CommandError
items.body:
It would probably be nice to expose the underlying error messages when somebody gets a CommandError. Right now we just show the code and message, but it would be nice to show whatever is in the 'errors' array at `result[-1]['data']['errors']` (if it exists), as those errors are usually the most explanatory. Perhaps they can automatically by joined into a single string—your call.

It would also be nice to store the remainder of the 'data' object in the CommandError (minus the inserted `enable` or `config terminal` commands), so people can see the responses of the other commands run before the error hit.

items.title: pyeapi.client.connect_to(node) should not raise KeyError if node is missing form the config
items.body: I think a more intuitive error message would be better: MissingNodeConfigurationError?
